DOC.HEAD: AT&T to Reduce Long Distance Rates
Eds: CORRECTS ``weekend'' to ``weekday'' in 5th graf: ``This would,''
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. announced today it will reduce rates by $300 million a year on interstate and international long-distance services used primarily by residential and small business customers. The price reductions will take effect Jan. 1, AT&T said The company said they would apply to its basic long-distance service plus international calls and the AT&T ``Reach Out America'' and optional long-distance plans. The reduction would be the company's 10th since 1984 and would bring total rate decreases to 40 percent in the six years since the breakup of the Bell System, the company announcement said. The company said a 10-minute call, at any time of day to anywhere in the United States, will cost $2.50 or less after the decrease takes effect. At night or on a weekend, such calls will cost $1.32 or less, it said. This would be a reduction of 1.3 percent on weekday calls and 2 percent on evening calls, the company said. AT&T said price cuts, filed today with the Federal Communications Commission, reflect reduced expenses, mainly from lower fees that the company will pay in 1990 to local telephone companies for access to customers' lines. Under FCC guidelines, those costs savings lower the price cap on AT&T long-distance services. The proposal includes: _A 1.3 percent drop in prices for basic long-distance service during the weekday calling period, which is 8 a.m. to 5. p.m. local time Monday through Friday, and a 2 percent drop during the evening period, 5 p.m. to 11 p.m. Sunday through Friday. _Increasing discounts for subscribers to the Reach Out America 24-hour plan from 5 percent to 10 percent on weekday calls and from 20 to 25 percent on evening calls, 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. Sunday through Friday. _A $104 million price slash on international calls from the U.S. mainland to 25 of the most frequently called countries and overseas areas, with the reductions varying by country and time of day. Countries include Canada, Mexico, Japan, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Israel, Brazil, Australia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Korea. _Reductions in the price of service to 39 countries by AT&T World Connect, which gives frequent international callers a discount on direct-dialed calls from the U.S. mainland. _A reduction in basic long-distance prices from Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands to 95 countries and territories.
